headline: Not the company they proclaim to be
author_position: Closing Specialist, Account Manager, Wire Specialist
pros:
flexible depending on they department 
free snack
cons:
Besides the mean girl atmosphere in the Production Department, I have been yelled at by a loan officer to the point that I ended up in Urgent care with a panic attack and on heart meds to this day because of it and the stress I was placed under. When moved to a new department and learning a new job the other departments that you have to work with are not patient or kind during that learning curve. There is a lot of pressure put upon the employees in some of the departments and very little forgiveness or understanding regardless of what their VU values claim. I have witnessed a lot of what I would call age discrimination and absolutely no consistency with they way they treat their employees. You may come out of training and get a team lead that rides you hard in a very unkind way and expects you keep up with all of your work within 3 months of being out on the floor but yet one of your peers who came out of training with you will get a different manager in the same department and their manager will be very kind and understanding and tell that employee that they are not expected to keep up with only being out on the floor for 3 months and will let them work overtime to keep up. The care nothing about being consistent and treating each employee fairly. HR knows about this issue but still no one fixes it and I have seen it A LOT. 
They claim to be a VU family however I have witnessed a top preforming employee get forced out of a job because her family, who babysit her infant, had planned a trip overseas for a month so she asked to work from home during that time so she could watch her child and work, which we have the capability to do and have done many times, and they told her no and not only that but then emailed all the other women on the team who had small children and let it be known that they should not ask either and childcare is not their problem. Since there is a shortage of infant childcare in our area, the woman had to leave the company and they would not even let her finish her two weeks. We had been working from home all through Covid so this makes no sense. 
If you are young and cute you will probably be ok if you get in good with the right people but God help you if you don't. I have heard many that have left the company say they have PTSP from working there. I could go on and on with many more stories but all I really want to do is forget this place. I do not recommend this company.

headline: It's a meat grinder
pros:
They pay fairly well. Although the separation in pay grades from loan officer to loan coordinator was made clear when it came to treatment. Multiple loan officers referred to coordinators as their assistant's without correction.

They try to innovate, maybe a little too fast. When hired, they trained my class for 3 different positions before settling on one. Every hiring class has a wildly different training experience. 

They do A LOT. Team outings, meals, tee shirts, hats, boots, free snacks. It can be stressful when you don't like combining your social life with work. And for the most part every event has alcohol. Great if you drink. Rough if you're sober.

Free Y pass.
cons:
There's definitely a correlation between who is determined to not be "a good fit" for VU, and who is visibly queer. On top of the fact despite having diversity and inclusion small groups, somehow the St. Louis office is 90% white. 

As a Loan Coordinator you're expected to be online and responding to questions 9am-5pm, while often times loan officers opt to only come in for part of the work day. This is a problem when you need help from them.

They're always re-working something. While it can be a good thing, it often left a sense of unease amongst teams. Keeping up with VU changes felt like a job in and of itself, outside of the normal changes that come with working on government backed loans. 

If the customer is mad- they will call you, and they will scream at you. Be it because they don't want to give you financial information, or you're just not able to make 3rd parties move any faster. 

They tell you it's a work hard/play hard roll, when it does not have to be. Putting all the pressure on the LC's to handle 40-50 loans at a time with a rotating door of underwriters, closers, loan officers, and more makes it pressure filled. Leaving major items up to "underwriter discretion" does.

All in all- this job can and will run you down.

headline: Inconsistent rules, rushing through loans, workload required overtime
pros:
Free snacks
Quick communication from HR, IT, etc
Team lead and managers did as much to help answer questions as possible, but they are overwhelmed themselves
401k
cons:
My experience at VU was a disappointing shock to me. In past positions at other companies I have always felt that even when the position was stressful, I was trained to handle it adequately. At VU, this was not the case.

 I went through training for three different positions within a year, because they kept moving me (along with many others) due to company needs. 

The training is inadequate. Though lots of time is spent on very specific items, such as taxes, there is not enough loan specific training and training on the full process of our position - in other words, we would focus on a skill, but end up feeling unprepared for our position as a whole. Trainers would imply to us that there is a correct way that they have to train us, but that once we are working our own pipeline, we may end up doing it differently (either skipping stuff because we are rushed, or being told to do something differently by our eventual team lead). Multiple people will advise differently on the exact same topic, making it difficult to learn what the current, true rule is. 

Trainers advised us over and over that our position was very stressful. They advised us that "you won't find a closing specialist that hasn't cried." This was not disclosed to me during any part of the recruitment process. In fact, the work life balance was highly touted, and the actual position description was avoided, because the recruiter did not know exactly which position I would placed into. 

The workload varied throughout the year but during a significant portion of my time at VU I was doing overtime to keep up with my workload, never taking breaks, and crying multiple times a week. I was truly clicking as fast as humanly possible and never giving my eyes a break, just to keep up with all my emails. 
The duties of each member assigned to a particular loan were not always clear. Many times it was hard to figure out if I was supposed to be doing something or if another member of the loan team was trying to get me to do their job for me. Communication was hit or miss, with some loan officers responding immediately, and some ignoring me until I cc'ed a manager. 

It seemed there was a motto of We can't train you on everything, you just have to learn gradually. But this type of method of learning is incredibly stressful when people are making demands that have to be met RIGHT now or else a loan can't close. If I didn't know how to do something, and couldn't figure it out, I was dependent on finding someone else to help, in a rush. Though most people would try to help, it was a stressful situation. Many swear words in the office.

Taking time off work felt impossible. Though teammates are supposed to pick up your work while you are gone, it always results in a mess. A million emails when you come back.

I felt like I was in this strange culture where some people actually liked their jobs but everyone else was miserable, but somehow the whole culture is around making everyone think VU is amazing even when it's not. The people around me were so depressed and I heard constant complaints. Some would say they hadn't peed all day because they were so busy. People in training were so stressed that they would say they cried about things.

The industry is just so incredibly difficult and complex - so I understand it is difficult at any mortgage company to learn how to be good at your position. But there are so many frustrating things about the way VU runs, and they can't just keep growing and growing and never developing truly experienced workers and only having turnover, because there need to be enough well trained people to help new people.

headline: Would take A LOT  for me to leave this company
pros: Veterans United has an excellent culture that focuses on improving the lives of others through hard work, integrity, passion, and having fun. The company is so involved in the local community, too, and the executives place the most emphasis and care into the human beings who work here. You are almost guaranteed to find satisfaction and be rewarded in your role, and if you can't find it in the job itself, you will find it in other places. Veterans United is MORE than just a job or an employer; it's a family! We look out for each other and care for one another day in and day out. I have met some of the most incredible people here and have made life-long friendships, and I mean truly life-long, genuine friendships. There is an entire department dedicated to company culture, and they provide some life-enhancing opportunities year round to fill our cups with development both in and out of the office. These opportunities include book small groups, hobby-focused social groups, fun events for employees and their family members, an extravagant Holiday Party, and much, much more. Employees also have the opportunity to give a percentage of their paycheck to our own non-profit, the Veterans United Foundation, that does AMAZING things for people and non-profits across the country. Overall, Veterans United cares deeply about the human experience and the well-being of its employees. They take care of us and invest in us, and people work here for the long-haul. It's an incredible place to work!
cons: Being such a successful company as a whole means we put in work! Long days and overtime are common, even though leadership does their best to promote and encourage taking breaks and finding balance between work and life outside of the office. It could also be argued that the pay is not amazing, but most employees are compensated fairly and appropriately for their specific job. There are plenty of opportunities for growth and bonuses, but that comes with hard (sometimes very hard) work to earn it.

headline: More than a Mortgage Company

headline: Boiler Room for Retail and customer service workers
pros: Benefits start day 1; clothing giveaways; Happy Hour
cons:
This company is a cult focused on the Boiler Room mentality. The fringe benefits (free food, t-shirts, socks, beer and alcohol) is a front to keep a "them vs. us mentality" when it comes to employees. The interview process is designed to show a prospect that their current employee doesn't "care" for them as a person like VU does. The problem is, VU doesn't care for anybody but VU either. They pay low commissions as they entice customer service empyees typically earning 40k to accept a flat 60k pay. This base is high for the industry, but when you're closing the loans expected, you're only making 30% of what you'd make on the open market.

They force all empyees to sign a non-compete, which if challenged would be completely unenforceable as it is way too broad...essentially it states you can never have another job if it requires you to do ANYTHING you're currently doing (this includes talking to customers, using a phone or computer, working in a team, etc). The non-compete does NOT mention anything about the mortgage industry, just leaves a blanket open statement.

The management team will often say "I've drunk the Kool-Aid", like it's a point of pride. This statement best suits the organization as it is most closely associated to a cult. Unfortunately, the statement is derived from a popular cult by which the cult followers were forced to drink poisonous Kool-aid and die, or they were shot dead with AK47s. This organization wants to have an appearance that everyone is family, they require you to be friends with your co-workers outside of work, they have stated many times that they would love to see the line of work-life balance gone and you don't know what is what. In the end, when you realize this isn't the right job, company, etc, you are fired on the spot, can't complete your loans under contract, they shut off all benefits that day, and essentially treat you like a deserter of the cult.

So, in summary, this company is like a circus ringmaster, raising a lion in captivity so the lion doesn't realize they are more powerful. For those looking to have a secure pay, and become a robot and "yes man", this is a great position. Don't ever leave. If you have aspirations and want to challenge yourself, this is the worse position for you.

I feel well supported in my role at home, and know I can reach out if I am having any issues. For example, when I first started working from home I had an unstable internet connection, so I was given a mifi router from the company to sustain an internet connection during the work day. cons: The work load cannot be done in 40 hours a week, so I am constantly working overtime. OT is unlimited, but its less appealing to get those extra hours when I don't feel there's a choice. I am told by my team leads that this work load is for my own growth and benefit, but my family and personal life have suffered as a result. For example, I have less time to help with the kids as they navigate online school. Lastly, not all VU employees embody the company's mission of enhancing lives. We should be treating ALL people with respect, not just the veterans our company serves. I don't get the impression loan officers and POCs understand what we're dealing with in processing. I work as hard as I can to serve our veterans and my loan team, and I consistently feel disrespected and undervalued by my own coworkers.

headline: Amazing Company!
pros:
CULTURE - this company is awesome. They're so supportive of their employees, veterans, and communities. Almost every employee donates 1% of their pay check to the VU foundation and VU gives it back in BIG ways. They have handled COVID and the pandemic amazingly. Sending all employees home at the beginning and working very carefully to get some back in the office while still keeping everyone safe and able to work from home. They check in about every month to make sure we are doing ok, those who are working from home still, and if we need anything. Bonus, they love to send us small gifts from time to time and will even mail it right to our house to keep us smiling. 
They are good about reaching out to tell you what a good job you are doing or to congratulate you on any big progress you've made. 
They're good at promoting from within, I've seen lots of people move up within the last year and they always reach out to us to let us know when new roles are opening up. 
They have never had layoffs.
Their core value are, Be Passionate, Deliver Results, and Enhance Lives - I can truly say the live and breath these values and push to help all of their employees understand them and live them as well.
cons:
When in the office, the cubicles are tiny and cramped. Lenexa office could really benefit from a bigger space.
Wish we had a little more PTO each year but its still competitive at 2 weeks starting right away. 
They have all the benefits but the cost of them does seem on the high side.

headline: They pay well because its horrible.
pros: Pay. Casual dress. Free soda machine.
cons: They are no different than anywhere else except the work is much more stressful and it follows you home.  Managers promote friends and don't tell the higher ups what is really going on.  So the higher ups think everything is good while the workers LITERALLY cry at their desks.  This is not an isolated occurrence.  LOTS of people openly cry at their desks from stress.  Very inconsistent rules on how to do your job.  One day you could do X and be fine.  The next day you do X and somebody different says thats totally wrong and won't accept it.  They constantly state they aren't concerned about growth, but they are constantly hiring more Loan Officers, but not support staff to go with it.  There is no room to grow.  They want entry level jobs to be careers so you will do the same thing for 20 years and never get promoted.  They SCREAM work/life balance is important, and then give you 60 hours of work and innocently wonder why it isn't done in 40.  I literally had to negotiate with my manager about hours of overtime needed when the higher ups DIDN'T CARE.  But guess what he got bonused on?  That's right, in order to get a bigger bonus, my manager would not let me do my full job which just leads to more stress because then I get in trouble with other people who were counting on me to do my job.  Their values/mission statement sound great, they just don't actually mean anything.  They pay great because they HAVE to.   Save yourself the mental anguish.  The managers are inexperienced and do not have the guts or knowledge to resolve conflicts.  Bandaids for bullet holes.  Just look at their social media.  Their charitable foundation does do good things.  But if you look, they do not do anything without it also being a photo op.  If you think, like everyone else, that "I can handle a bad job if the pay is good enough."  just don't.  The only reason turnover isn't higher than it already is, is because people feel trapped.  Do not trap yourself with Veterans United Home Loans.  Oh, also while employed I used them to purchase and later refinance my own home.  They took so long doing it and messed it up so much, they had to give me like $600 in credit to stay in compliance.  And on the purchase, the manager that worked on it had my cash to close estimate wrong by around $3,000.  Yep, managers do not know the jobs they manage.

headline: Great Potential, But Doesn't Deliver
pros: The people you work with on a daily basis are genuinely great people.   There is usually flexibility in your daily schedule, I could come and go as I pleased during the day and no one cared.  You get the freedom to captain your own ship, and I really did love that.   If you're looking for a decent paying job while you transition to something else within a year or so, this is a great place to work.
cons:
Veterans United has created a high stress environment for those who work in production.  They chronically over hire loan officers, making it tough to meet sales requirements, and they chronically under-hire support staff like Account Managers, Assistants, and Underwriters.  In other words, getting business is difficult-- involving many nights and weekends away from your home life -- and the deals you do get are often sabotaged by the poor infrastructure of the company.   There was a point where it was taking almost 7 days to have an "in-house" underwriter review a loan.  That has gotten better, but could be much better.  
The pay structure is not great for loan officers.   This is a high-pressure sales job and loan officers are expected to be licensed experts, knowledgeable of corporate and federal guidelines for multiple loan products, maintain elite level customer service scores, and maintain a high score on a range of internal metrics.   Folks working in this job expect to be paid on a commission basis for their sales and VU has decided that it's more important for the owners to have private jets and homes on private islands than it is to properly take care of their talented work force.   
There is differential treatment of the loan officers regarding the pay scale.  There are some loan officers at the company who are able to earn a high commission solely because they were hired before a certain date and in most cases those loan officers have a huge team that does 80% of their work for them.  Meanwhile, other loan officers are paid hourly, must close 6 loans a month, and are required to PAY BACK THEIR OVERTIME.   In other words, you're working for free if you work over 40 hours, and you almost always work over 40.  Any bonus you earned would be confiscated to pay off your debt log.  The debt log also included appraisals for deals that fell through, often times for reasons beyond your control.  (Appraisals, on average, are between $500 and $750 each.) I would do the same amount of work and earn half the income as the guy next to me.   It's not enough for them to just be a successful company, they now have to be #1 in the country in terms of volume.  Of course, this is done on the backs of their employees and the company reaps the benefits.  
It is impossible to leave for vacation.  Taking a day off is no big deal, but taking a week off sets you back so far that it makes you unable to even enjoy your vacation while you're away from work.    Not to mention that even while you're gone you'll still be answering calls and emails from clients (and coworkers who are covering for you) --  constantly.   
The work space is unacceptable for adults working in this industry.  Loan officers at Veterans United work shoulder to shoulder in cubicles, like minimum wage workers at a customer service call center.   A loan officer at any other bank would have an office or a private work space to carry out their business while working with a borrower's personal and confidential information.  A professional working in this industry would be turned off knowing they would have to work in that kind of environment.  Simply unprofessional.  Have an upset client?  You'll be taking that call in front of about 15 other people unless you walk outside the building.  But at the end of the day, VU is a loan mill that found a niche in the mortgage market that was immune to the market crash (VA loans), and they take advantage of our nation's finest to make a buck.   They routinely give loans to folks fresh out of bankruptcy, short sales, etc.   They just want to close the deal, and the VA loan makes it easy.   
The VU foundation is funded by donations directly from the salaries of employees (I myself donated), yet the company takes the credit for the work the foundation does.   They get the credit and keep their money.   It's a win/win for VU.

I absolutely love what I do. VU is top notch all around.

headline: VU is the most unique company around - none better!
pros: I have worked in a variety of companies from very corporate to local businesses.  This company has a culture unlike any I have ever seen.  Let’s start with the perks – like the free vending and soda machines or the catered breakfasts and lunches or all the free swag they give away.  They provide free gym memberships and a free healthy snack fridge.  The dress code is extremely casual.  There are annual events like “Field Day” and the Christmas party but throughout the year there are luaus, crawfish boils, game days, pancake days, campouts, holiday parties for kids, I could go on all day.  They truly emphasize a work hard play hard mentality.  Compensation and pay are very comparable to other companies and VU loves to promote from within so if you can get in at an entry level position, career growth is only limited by your own determination and hard work.  But the reason I love this company so much is that employees are treated like people, not numbers.  Upper management and executives care about the employees happiness and well-being – it feels very much like a family.
cons: The jobs are very competitive and it's hard to get in the door.  Everyone wants to work at VU so they have their pick.  You can be very qualified and still not get hired.

headline: Probably the Best All Around Company I'll Ever Work For
pros:
VU is like no other employer. It was my first job out of college and I'm already convinced I'll never work at another place as great as VU unless I open up my own business one day. The culture there is second to none. You get to know GREAT people who work hard, have fun, and do their best to make other people's lives better every day. 

The compensation was good. Perks were great - they appreciate and take care of their employees. Great place to start a career. Since leaving VU and moving back closer to home I have had the opportunity to work for a Major League Baseball team and looking back a year later - even working in MLB doesn't compare to VU. 

I would recommend working here to anyone I know. I still stay in touch with a handful of people I worked with here and look forward to visiting again soon. The sky is the limit at VU - I hope the culture, their employees and upper management never changes as the company continues to grow and get larger.
cons: Just like any job as a loan officer (sales) you will work a lot of hours and to succeed you'll be there late nights and weekends. This isn't necessarily a con of VU or the job, just something that comes with being in sales and doing loans.

headline: Truly Amazing
pros: Everything. I have worked in many professions for both big and small companies. I have never found a company that cares for it's employees and customers the way that VU does. From the first day I showed up to work I was welcomed as if I had been there for 10 years. They are committed to their values. Not only during work hours but even outside of work. Management has a true open door policy and they are never to busy to stop and just chat for a few moments and that includes all of the executives and owners even. I truly feel part of a family working here and every person truly cares as much about each customer and the experience we give them as we do each other.
cons: There are no perfect companies in the world and everyone has room to grow and improve all the time. I can say without a doubt though that Veterans United is as close as you will find to it. The only negative that I would point out here would be that sometimes being a company that is spread out so much, it can make it hard to keep communication going on issues and culture can definitely be difficult to stay on top of, but they are doing a fantastic job of doing it. They constantly look for ways to improve not only for employees but for customer experience too.

headline: All of the rumors are true--but it's no easy job
pros:
The work is challenging, but everyone around you genuinely wants you to succeed and will do anything you ask (or don't ask) them to do to help you.

You are valued, respected, and treated well. Your victories don't go unnoticed, and you are rewarded generously for your hard work.

The training program is rigorous, which is super important--the job is hard! You definitely don't feel under-prepared when you finish your training. You can tell they want you to do well and give you every tool to be a success.

The company wants you to stick around! It's incredibly obvious that they want their employees to be here for the long haul--and they definitely give you the incentives to stay. I'm so spoiled working here I don't know that I'll be employable anywhere else that doesn't do everything VU does for us.

Even upper management knows your name (if they're in the same building as you), they'll greet you and ask how your weekend was, they'll go to happy hour with you, they really care!
cons: It's not easy! People hear all about the parties and perks, but the job is really hard--that's why we get all of the fun perks, because if you didn't have the fun, silly things to balance it out, people would burn out.

headline: Amazing company!
pros:
I've worked at Veterans United for about four months now, and I can easily say it's the best company I've ever been a part of. About a year ago, they implemented a pretty solid two-month training course for new Account Managers that's been extremely beneficial. I was really impressed with the training I received. 

VU is an incredibly proactive company when it comes to making changes that are needed in order to improve process efficiency. They live their values and base pretty much all of their major decisions on upholding those values. 

Most importantly, they take care of their employees and genuinely want what's best for them. Very rewarding company to work for. That's a rare characteristic in any industry, but especially hard to find in the financial services industry.
cons:
Most of the negative comments I've seen are because the company is going through some growing pains. They have grown exponentially the past couple of years, and it seems like they are improving processes and hiring in order to keep up with the growth. I honestly don't see this as a con (having work to do is never a bad thing), but I can see where that can be a frustrating factor for some people. Most of the Account Managers are stressed right now because the summer is busy, and new employees are getting up to speed. Again, not necessarily a con since the company is taking steps to improve this, but it is a result of the growth and therefore a current reality. 

The family health insurance packages are honestly not that great, and could be a bit more competitive. Deductibles are fairly high in relation to the monthly premiums.

headline: Customer Service Representative (Call Center)
pros:
I worked overnight so my job was extremely easy, I was assigned a little bit of busy work since I didn't get that many calls but it only lasted an hour or two, and out of an 8 hour shift that isn't that bad. Amazing pay, gifts from the company (just because), you get a raise after 6 months (usually), and amazing co-workers (not that I got to see them that much since I worked overnight)! You're part of a team and every once in a while you will do cool activities to get to know each other, paid for by the company (you don't have to participate if you don't want to!) I got to go to Paint the Town for free, and got free Panera and BBQ on a few different occasions! Also, you will get to participate in Field Day and the Call Center Casino Night! I won free Cardinals tickets and a bluetooth speaker, and it was my first time playing those kinds of games. In the office there's a free vending machine, free soda machine, constant support from team leads, coworkers, and even your boss, a couple slides in the buildings, and countless clubs and teams to join through the company! Man, this place is great and I really mean it. I was so happy to have the opportunity to work here. 
Also, if you are looking to move up in the company, this is the place to be! You don't even need a college degree, work in the call center long enough and you can study for a higher position and test into it! And everyone is really supportive and encourages you to do so!
cons:
Although I love the company and I feel like leaving was probably a dumb decision, there are reasons nonetheless. Working in the call center means sitting in a chair for 8 hours. You do get two or three 15 minute breaks, but sitting down for that long was really hard for me. I suppose you can get a stand-up desk which many people do, but it just seemed uncomfortable to me. VU is growing very rapidly, so if you work during the day, you will receive call after call after call without a lot of time in between each one. Therefore, the day-shift is something I was not interested in doing, I did a few and it was so monotonous I wanted to rip my hair out! However, this was my first call center job and I realized that it just wasn't for me. Nothing against VU's call center specifically. 
Watch out because the vending machine is free, along with the soda machine, and very often you will find free doughnuts in the break room along with free pizza, chicken, tacos or whatever they are providing for lunch that day! (They do this occasionally, but not every day) What's so bad about that? Well, its super hard to resist, and you might gain some weight. But I also have poor self control, so if you're better than me or you just don't care that much, then disregard this complaint! The real reason I left though is because I am returning to school and my overnight shift won't work with my schedule. Also, working with one other person gets kind of lonely. The day shift is full of friendly people though, and it is very easy to make friends! Since the day shift is so busy however, I wasn't interested in it. Even if I was though, it takes months to get your schedule changed...which brings me to Advice to Management.

headline: Seriously???
pros:
I did that to grab your attention... When I heard about VU from a friend a few years ago, I wasn't looking for a new opportunity.  But I thought at the time it would be a great place to work IF just half of what he said was true..  After finishing my first year  I can say that it is and more and I'm not prone to exaggeration.
A fast-paced, growing environment with no end in sight, VU is the first company for which I've worked that puts such a heavy, day-to-day emphasis on their company values- so much so that they are a large portion the annual employee review.
Management is very transparent:  part of the company-wide emphasis this year has been Trust- in yourself, your team members, and the Company as whole- all are encouraged to extend trust and work to develop trust with others.
Compensations are generous and random- from walking into the office one morning and getting a box of candy at my desk with a note from the CEO telling me (and every other qualifying employee) VU just plunked $1000 into my 401(k)-  Seriously???  To naming all employees Employee Of The Year at the Christmas Party and putting ANOTHER $3000 in our 401(k)'s-SERIOUSLY???  VU is serious about each employee's future and they show it by leading the way in committing resources to each employees future, not only their own.
cons: There can be a sense of employee entitlement at times-because the company is so generous the expectation level increases.  Sounds crazy, but yeah, it happens.

cons: Not really any downsides. I am scarred for life and won't be able to work any place that isn't like this one. :)

headline: Great Place to work!
pros: I love working at VU. They are passionate about the customers and employees. Coming from corporate America, working here has been a breath of fresh air!
cons: Advancement is not the easiest, but as the company continues to grow I believe that will improve.

headline: Passion, Culture, Compensation.
pros: VU is as close to perfect as one could ever find.  The people, from top to bottom, love what they do and who they help.  It doesn't hurt that the company spoils its team (in a good way) across the board with great office perks and compensation.
cons: I struggle to come up with much.  Honestly, the distributed office situation can make for a bit of an annoyance at times but that's really grasping at straws.

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Company looks out for overall best interest of everyone. Lots of opportunities to learn. Strong culture and belief in good work/life balance. Work family.
cons: Can be difficult to move up from certain positions.

headline: Great Culture but left wanting
pros: The people are fantastic. I can not say enough about my old co-workers and the care they all have for each other. Management and HR truly want to get to know everyone.
cons: Cons: Lack of focus at times; can be too flexible; health insurance was expensive!; some jobs seriously tedious

headline: Great company
pros: Really cares about their employees.  Fun and everyone really cares!
cons: Can be stressful and busy at times

headline: Good overall, some struggles
pros: Most of the people that work at VU are dedicated and caring individuals. The top executives are engaged with their workers and really go all out to make us feel welcome here. The atmosphere is very laid back and friendly. The team building events are fun and happen often enough to keep employees happy. Most managers are outgoing and don't breath down your neck or make you feel like you are lesser. Free food and free massages. The Christmas parties are a blast!
cons: The constant growth means that you will never stay in one place for long, and the continuous movement affects team output. There needs to be more willing hands to help backed up departments. A little tired of seeing extremely busy departments that struggle to get done by the end of the day versus departments that appear to have a lot of people not doing much. Not all managers and team leads are competent or engaged. Like others have said, there are a few that persist at VU simply because they've been here a long time and have connections. Sometimes good employees get thrown under the bus by bad management. The benefits package isn't the greatest. You only get 2 weeks a year and that includes both sick time and vacation. They do add time after you've been with the company a certain amount of years.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Very caring company with some seriously cool marketing prowess - the marketing team was seriously top-notch.
cons: The developer side of stuff was lacking. PHP + MySQL + wild west spaghetti code. I've heard its a bit better now - but if you want a cutting edge, best practice sort of workplace - this is probably not it.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great culture, very laid back, no dress code, friendly people, company sponsored events are common and fun, friendly work environment, they are open to new ideas and will implement employee suggestions after a short and straightforward review process.  Great pay and good benefits.
cons: If you don't fit in well with the culture or subscribe to their values then it is not the place for you.  The open work environment, while being a plus, can get loud.

headline: Part Time as an Applications Developer Intern
pros:
- Amazing Agile work environment
- Learn an insane amount about different systems and development practices
- Extremely good learning experience since VU is so focused on Pairing
- Competitive salary
- Awesome company events
- Allows for part time development during the school year
cons: - If you don't like an open floor plan for development or Paired Programming, you'd probably be uncomfortable

headline: Great place to work
pros: Transparent, open atmosphere.  The company values, Be passionate and have fun, Deliver results with integrity, Enhance lives every day are exhibited by many in the company. More than 98% of the company employees contribute 1% of their salary to the company non profit foundation. That foundation does incredible things for the local community and for veterans nationwide. You work hard, but it is with people that are fun.
cons:
It began as a small company. It has grown very fast, very quickly. There have been growing pains with that growth. Some in management are there because they "have been there" rather than actually being good managers. 

Retirement benefits are not great. There is a $1200 match.

headline: Great place to work (mostly)
pros: Phenomenal, talented and awesome co-workers. The two founders absolutely love their employees, the community, and the veterans they serve. Lots more fringe benefits and better work environment than anywhere else in the finance and real estate industries.
cons: Not such a good environment for tech workers. The technology management never seemed interested in understanding, validating or addressing the concerns of individual workers. Management never trusted tech workers to make the right decisions, always wanted them chained at their desks and told which tools to use to do their jobs (even when it didn't make sense.) This may be common in the real estate industry (I don't know) but is unheard of in technology and most of the good developers quickly left. Management never felt obligated to explain or justify any decision. The compensation also lagged behind other tech employers.

headline: Fun Place to Work to Gain Experience
pros: The company does have some great perks, free massages, great holiday parties, free snacks and drinks, and the atmosphere can be fun. Almost everyone I know and work with, work hard and have a strong work ethic. The people are really great (for the most part) and honestly are my favorite part of the job. They do have matching for your 401k/IRA, which is great and the pay depending on your position can be quite good.
cons: It can be really hard to gain any sort of upward movement in your career path, unless you know the right people. It has been shown on numerous occasions that lesser qualified people were chosen for jobs based on their connections and not their ability to perform the job. The job is also very stressful and depending on the department, there can be loads of overtime that occurs. Recently switched up medical plans which drastically increased prices, before the medical plan was pretty decent and now with the increase, it is pretty miserable.

headline: Great place to work.
pros: Great atmosphere and benefits.  Management is top quality and very attentive to input from employees.  Culture and values are very important.  Pay is very competitive for the area and you get the work with our Nation's Heros every day, couldn't ask for much more.
cons: Limited opportunities for growth in the company.  It is a young company with young executives and management, so don't expect them to be retiring and making way for new blood any time soon.

headline: Closing Specialist
pros: Great perks and great work environment companywide. Awesome work events and great ways of making the new people feel welcome. Also got tons of new work apparel with all of the free t-shirts!
cons: Not enough training for people who have never worked in the finance industry before. More entry level positions should be available for those without that experience in finance or more one-on-one training, or extensive training for those individuals.

headline: Account Manager aka Dream Job
pros: Almost 3 months into working here, I still catch myself wondering when the "work" is really going to start. What I mean by this statement is VU treats its employees like real human beings, like a family. The company understands the never-ending strains and pressures that come with working in the mortgage industry, and does everything possibly to foster an enjoyable, yet successful workplace. No doubt the workload can be overbearing at times, but VU strives to make sure this workload is being done in the most efficient way possible, and we are having fun all along the way.
cons: The company is growing like crazy so with that comes growing pains, constant changes, and communication issues. Adaptability and openness to learning are absolute musts to thrive here.

headline: Great job!
pros: I am still fairly new here at VU, but I am loving every minute. The co-workers are very friendly and helpful, the training is thorough, and the perks are just the cherry on top!
cons: I don't really have any cons yet, except that I wish I would have applied here much sooner.

headline: Closing Specialist
pros: The training team is fantastic.  Everyone I’ve talked to in the office or via IM and email has been helpful and positive.  Did I mention the food?  VU provides lunch occasionally and snacks and soda.  I sincerely appreciate it and don’t ever want to take these things for granted.  We recently received a bonus.  I had been employed less than 30 days and had done nothing to earn it yet.  Speaking of grace, I love that VU supports spiritual growth.
cons: The training process is long and at times I feel I don't have control of my schedule.  I'm sure this will pass once I'm trained.

headline: It was a good run
pros: Plenty of opportunity for gaining marketable technical skills.  I enjoyed most of the people I worked with.
cons: Negotiate your salary upfront, b/c you aren't going to get any significant raise (if any) without timing your intention to leave perfectly.  Benefits are meh.  Not many employment options in Columbia, but these guys are up top with what's available.

headline: Awesome
pros: Good pay plus commission, good benefits, fun environment, tons of perks, lots of employee events, awesome company values, donate a lot to charity
cons: Work under pressure to meet deadlines and customer needs, have to learn very quickly and mostly on the fly.

headline: Intern
pros: Great company, they really value their employees and find ways to make work a home away from home. The orientation was awesome they bought us lunch, introduced the company to us, took us to make custom t-shirts, bowling, and to get ice cream. They give free lunch every Monday, free vending machines, stocked refrigerator, free drinks etc. They are very flexible and overall just a wonderful place to work. Glad I chose to intern here!
cons: The only con is I wish they had more locations around the U.S!

headline: Poor organization and management in operations department
pros: Culture. Coworkers. Fringe-benefits/perks. Relaxed atmosphere. Events. Foundation. Commitment to their cause.
cons: Terrible management of the operations department, extremely ineffective communication, lack of cohesion between departments. Lack of good leadership. Inexperienced managers due to quick growth in recent years. Minimal increase in salary, doesn't meet cost of living inflation in most cases. Inconsistency in reviews, raises and promotions.

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: Fun atmosphere, great co-workers and many opportunities for professional development. I love that the company values are so important to employees -- it makes VU a great place to work!
cons: I really don't see any cons.

headline: Great if you are interested in finding drinking buddies...not great if you are looking to advance your career
pros: Free vending machines and a fresh fruit, a Christmas party that is insane, Field Day, VU foundation and the stories that are produced
cons: Raises are on average 1.5%, thick middle management layer with slim to no experience, expensive health benefits, promotions seem to be based on how and who you spend your free time with instead of the value you deliver for the business.

headline: Great company
pros: Friendly people, positive work environment and lots of access to resources including professional development. They emphasize a healthy work/life balance and are always encouraging staff to live according to company values.
cons: There really aren't any major cons, but I will say inter-departmental communication isn't the best, I think it's something they are constantly trying to improve.

headline: Great Company. Great Culture.
pros: Fun, friendly atmosphere that made you want to come into work. Great benefits all around. I worked in marketing, and the senior and mid level management were experts in their fields, so I came away with a better internship experience than most of my peers.
cons: None really. I was offered a job after graduating, but I wanted to move out of Columbia. Otherwise I definitely would have stayed at the company.

headline: Current Satisfied Employee
pros: Lots of perks; free vending machines, free monday lunches & gym membership paid for to name a few.
cons: Summer is demanding, training could be better, there could be better communication across departments.

headline: Love it.
pros: Company really values its employees. Good life work balance and opportunities to further your career.
cons: No cons that I can think of at the top of my head.

headline: Fun Company and Culture, So-So ethics and release procedure
pros:
- Great People, Young Company
- Fun Atmosphere
- Lots of group activities 
- "Google-like" environment
- Stocked fridge/free lunch on Mondays
cons:
- Company hires too many people and then lets them go like it's no big deal
- You could be let go at any minute without knowing how, when or why
- CEO and top execs are great, but HR needs to be re-done

headline: No such thing as a free lunch
pros:
Good pay
fun distractions
awesome christmas party
cons:
chronic under-staffing makes everyone overworked
unprofessional team leads
inadequate training

headline: Underwriter
pros: Everything. Never worked somewhere that cared about it's employees so much. Treated as fair as  you could ever expect.
cons: Nothing. No idea what 'Loan Officer" is talking about with PTO. I have trouble using up my PTO I have so much.

headline: Loan officer
pros: Great people, great environment, lots of perks
cons: Insurance coverage is only ok, PTO plan for non-sales employees is rough.

headline: Awesome
pros: Absolutely fantastic place to work!!!
cons: Nothing. I love it here.

headline: Zero work life balance
pros: nice people, young company, free lunch once a week
cons: no work life balance they are constantly adding more to the position you were hired for.  If you take a day off you spend the next 2-3 days getting caught up.  Expected to work weekends and 10-12 hours per day

headline: Great place
pros: Competitive pay, benefits, coworkers, work-life balance, mobility.
cons: The culture can be bro-y at times, but otherwise very laid back.

headline: it was great
pros: Fantastic company with great benefits a great environment that has a family atmosphere and work with you when you feel unsuccessful.
cons: Can be very stressful and work is very fast paced so make sure to know your strengths beforehand.

headline: Account Manager
pros: I love what they stand for and how they work with the community. I enjoyed knowing that I was actually benefiting a Veteran either with community service or getting them into their home. There were many rewarding things if you were able to fully do your job.
cons: Very unorganized and lack the compensation for work done. I was there for 7 months and my training was always the last priority. By the time I left I wasn't even able to fully do what my job requirements asked. I was short changed on my experience there.

headline: Customer Service Specialist (Call Center)
pros:
I have met some of the most amazing people at this company! VU is such a community workplace. The way that the company treats its employees is unparalleled. I work in the call center and the atmosphere is always fun and upbeat but also relaxed. The management is very constructive and never negative. The company has events all the time to celebrate achievements and the employees and they never disappoint. 

There are PLENTY of opportunities to move up in the company. Starting in the call center is a great way to get your foot in the door, for VERY decent pay in an entry level position. 

I found out I was pregnant about 4 weeks after I started and my manager's first words when I told him were "That's so awesome! Congrats!" (VU has 5 weeks of paid maternity leave btw!) They are so positive here! If you have a chance to work here, DO NOT SAY NO!
cons: No cons to think of as long as you are willing to do the work and live by the VU values. I've been here for 8 months and I still love it just as much as when I started!

headline: Very busy, yet still encouraged to indulge time in success and fundraising.
author_position: Loan Officer Assistant to Branch Manager
pros: Fun environment. Great benefits. Business keeps growing and growing. It's a wonderful place to work and feeling that you can approach upper management with concerns and they offer positive feedback often to employees.
cons: Our Branch Closed. Our Branch Closed.Our Branch Closed.Our Branch Closed.

headline: Passionate, Enhancing and Fun!
pros: I absolutely love working for such an amazing company.  Supervisors and co-workers are amazingly supportive and it's a joy to see smiles every day when I get to the office.  The CEO of the company is down-to-earth and every other "higher-up" I've met has been incredible!
cons: Absolutely none!  This is a great place to work.

headline: Very rewarding, fast paced environment.
pros: This company doesn't treat their values as just words, they live them out everyday. It is also very rewarding that we get the opportunity to serve those that have served our country. I also am at the Columbia location which is the corporate headquarters and I think that it's cool to see the CEO and other high ups and daily basis.
cons: The workload can be a little overwhelming at times but to me that just means work stability.

headline: Get a little experience and move on
pros:
-Good company to start & get experience 
-Host lots of family oriented events
-Free lunches (though not weekly like used to be)
-Do great work for a great cause (veterans)
cons:
There is no long term planning at the company.  For upper management, long term means about 7 days.  There is mass hiring, followed by lay offs, followed a few days later by more hiring to replace the people laid off.  Saw this cycle multiple times while there.  It was disappointing see some quality co-workers get let go or moved to another role to make room for a relative or friend of management.  Benefits and compensation are mediocre for the industry.
Ultimately, its a good place to get your feet wet and have a little fun, but the novelty will wear off quick once the realization sets in that there is no chance at development or movement in the company.

headline: Loan Officer job is more than meets the eye.
pros: Casual work environment is nice. Like the other LO's I work with. Local underwriting team is wonderful. Leads provided so you can focus on production.
cons: File processing team is far below par. Difficult to work with individual processors as well as managers. Lack of consistency in accountability between departments. Managers are unprofessional in their handling of HR matters. Lack of clarity in job descriptions and responsibility. Seems to be purposeful to paying full commissions due to all responsibility landing on LO's although they have the least control over outcomes.

headline: Great perks, but prepare to be overworked
pros: What VU does is awesome, helping serve those who have served the country. The foundation we have does amazing things, not only for veterans, but for local people and for the employees. Everyone at VU is very family oriented and its really easy to make close friends here. The way the company treas the employees with perks and company events is a rarity in the corporate world. The pay is pretty decent, depending on your position. Most departments do live up to the company value of "be passionate and have fun",
cons: Processing in particular has had a very rough time keeping up with production demands. As soon as one part of the department is adequately staffed, another part is grossly understaffed due to moving people around too much. Its not uncommon for people to work 50-60 hour weeks, plus mandatory weekends on top of that. The executive leadership of the company does genuinely care about their employees, but I feel like the message doesn't filter down through the levels of management to make the people who actually do all the work to close the loans feel appreciated enough. The communication from management tends to be lacking as well. There is hardly any opportunity for growth, and often it seems like you have to be buddies with the hiring manager to get promoted, even if other people had better credentials.

headline: Wow
pros: Hands down the best company to work for. Work hard play hard. They treat employees like gold. Anyone with a negative attitude is likely too green in the professional world to understand 99% of companies don't treat employees like this. Did I mention we serve our Vets every day? What can be more rewarding than that?
cons: When I hear someone complain the free snack machine is out of chips... Seriously?

headline: On the fence.
pros: Fun, flexible environment that allows good work life balance.
cons: Not room for development for everyone, namely production.  Only interested in developing middle management.

headline: Approach With Caution
pros: Friendly co-workers; casual dress, fun activities.
cons: Quality of management varies by department.  It truly is an "at-will" employment arrangement.

headline: Lovely
pros: really relaxed workplace. Really I'm only reviewing them so I can unlock the rest of this site
cons: growing very very quickly! Can be hard to

headline: Great company, highly inexperienced managers that lack accountability
pros: The charitable arm of Veterans United (Veterans United Foundation) and the Corporate Office (known as "Home Office") is fantastic.  The majority of the management team is very supportive and continually demonstrates their commitment by going above and beyond.  Overall, it appears that the executive team and division leaders (at Home Office) all have a true passion for the cause and it's a shame that a few bad apples completely ruined what many of us felt was the opportunity of a lifetime to work for an incredible company that truly deserves to be an industry leader.
cons: The executive team is very disconnected from the actual branches.  Our "leaders" that were responsible for guiding us within our market were very unethical and got away with very unfavorable business practices.  As other reviewers previously stated, Veterans United should immediately terminate employees for unethical and compromising patterns of behavior.  After exposing our team to a great deal of stress and countless internal audits and investigations, the decision was finally made to terminate several of the individuals that were setting us back from flourishing.  Sadly enough, these changes occurred far too late and many of our team members were essentially forced to resign due to the unstable environment, lack of support and sheer ignorance on behalf of management.  In the end, the unethical employees were terminated but it is a shame so many others previously resigned and the changes we not initiated sooner.

headline: Extremely positive.
pros: The managers are terrific and they have integrity.
cons: There are lots of changes o keep up with, but that goes with the industry.

headline: I will never find a better employer
pros: The culture is second to none. Every Exec makes an effort to get to know each and every employee
cons: I did not enjoy the mortgage business.

headline: Easily the Best Place I Have Worked in Columbia
pros: Fantastic co-workers, great values, relaxed work environment.
cons: Cannot think of anything negative that stands out.

headline: Rewarding but hard work
pros: Pay, flexible hours, work environment
cons:
50+ hours per week
Stressful
Pressure to hit numbers

headline: Freindly environment
pros: Great co-workers, catered lunch Fridays, in house masseuse, many opportunities to advance.
cons: Very few cons actually, the management is easy to work with and the co-workers are great - I hada far better experience here than almost anywhere else I've worked

headline: Good company for early experience
pros: Great for young employees to learn the ropes, especially for marketing. The marketing team is one of the best you'll find in the midwest.
cons: Scaled up quickly so lost some of the touch from early days. Sometimes keeps around deadweight that should be cut.

headline: This is an incredible place to work.
pros: Free Monday lunches, free snacks, fun Company events, caring co-workers
cons: Lower compensation to start, parking can be tricky

headline: Awesome place to work with great people
pros: They really care about you as a person and an employee. Fun place to work. People are very nice. Veterans United Home Loans makes sure you're comfortable. And if you are not for any reason they really want to know.
cons: There can be an exclusionary feeling among some people around the office. Also some people have become comfortable with their job and complain when huge perks like free food and candy go away.

headline: Company that cares about its employees
pros: Promote a good balance between work and home.
cons: Fast growing, lots of changes.

headline: Veterans United Home Loans, Columbia Mo
pros: People, Culture, values, location, environment
cons: Forecasting department is not the greatest.

headline: Best Company in Columbia
pros: Veterans United is forward-thinking.  They hire extremely high caliber people and are rapid to change, which scares some people away but is actually refreshing. There is not some huge bureaucratic process that has to happen for change to take place. The executives are oriented towards the future of the company and committed to employing only the best people.   The culture is fun and the work is rewarding.
cons: Slackers beware--if you don't work hard, you'll get let go.

headline: Even though there has been a lot of recechanges within the company, it is still the best company I have ever worked for.
pros: Lots of perks. Most managers seem to really care about their employees. The company is very family oriented. Employees are expected to work hard and most employees are passionate about their jobs.
cons: Seem to be unorganized at times and I feel like changes aren't always thought through. Company-wide communication is also lacking.

headline: Don't leave a good job to come to work for this company.
pros: Casual dress, above average pay, get to help out veterans, and the free taxi rides home from company events
cons: Immediate supervisors are not helpful, lack of training, lack of help, the company has grown too big too fast and it is on the downward trend. There is no Monday catered lunch, free t-shirts are rare, and if you have a good job and like it, then do NOT leave it to work for this company.

headline: Great company overall.
pros: Work equality, pay is fairly competitive.
cons: Way too much micromanagement from less-qualified individuals who make up senior roles. Not many folks have real world experience.

headline: Challenging and rewarding.  It's nice to be surrounded by good people every day.
pros: New challenges every day, making a difference for veterans, and working with good people.
cons: Yeah, I don't think so.

headline: Go to work in your most comfortable clothes and spend the day enhancing lives.
pros: Free Monday lunches as well as beverages and snacks daily, casual attire, great benefits package, unlimited opportunity for personal growth, volunteerism promoted, amazing co-workers, and innovation highly encouraged.
cons: If you aren't adaptable to change, this is not an environment which will suit you; positions are sometimes defined by the employees, so if you don't work well with minimal supervision...you need not apply!

headline: Do not leave a good position for a job here
pros: The company values are great and the company seems to have a genuine desire to do good in the community as well as for its employees and customers.
cons:
Before coming to work here, be sure that you know who you will be working for and exactly what you will be doing.  Unfortunately, I was reeled in by all of the great reviews here on Glass Door as well as knowing a couple of former co-workers who said they enjoyed it.  I left a professional position to join VUHL and within two months, I regretted it.  I was thrown into a different position than the one I was hired for and eventually ended up working for an incompetent manager which lead me to leave their employment.

This was a very frustrating place to work.  Due to favoritism, some employees can get away with surfing the web, watching YouTube, disappearing for long periods of time, not answering emails for days, etc while others who spend their time actually working would get chastised for abstract things that cannot be measured.  

The long and short of it is that, at this time, this is not a company where someone who wants to be treated fairly should work.  Leaving my old position to work here was the biggest mistake of my life and I truly hope this post will help others from making the same mistake.

While the company values are great, they are meaningless if they are not enforced on a consistent basis as integrity is greatly lacking with some.

headline: Great, agile company that appreciates creativity and hard work.
pros: Everyone genuinely cares about what they do, and the people they serve. They really stand by their values, and have done a good job at getting the best out of young and ambitious people. I don't know that anyone else in Columbia could get as much quality out of their employees as Veterans United has.
cons: Since they are a young company who likes to promote from within, their mid level managers don't necessarily have the leadership and development skills to make the people under them better. They are developing and are generally strong performers, but don't have the maturity to develop their teams.

headline: A great place to start, a poor place to land.
pros: The company culture is phenomenal.  It is fun to go to work for a couple of years with other young professionals who are highly motivated and energetic.  The company has it's heart in the right place with philanthropy and service to the community.
cons: You're worked extremely hard as an account manager for very little recognition and little chance of upward movement.  Professional development at VUHL is virtually non-existent and so are genuine career opportunities.  It's a good place to go to work to gain a little professional experience and pad your resume, however, it isn't going to offer the long-term career progression.  Benefits are pretty average (they throw a lot of "freebies" in your face but don't offer much in line of retirement, work-life-balance, or tuition reimbursement).

headline: Awesome place to work!
pros: Company cares about it's employees!
cons: People don't seem to stick around too long.

headline: One of the best places to start a career after college
pros: Catered lunches on Mondays, always casual dress, flexible hours, free vending machine, free refrigerator (full of fresh fruit, veggies, cheeses, and drinks), free soda fountain, free massage every other week, very youthful workplace, so many great company activities and outings, very philanthropic company, overall really fun place to work. I'd say only Google has us beat as far as taking care of employees (but we're continually improving).
cons: Parking is a nightmare, some of the positions seem really underpaid compared to other departments, and sometimes you can get pulled to another team to help them out with busy projects.

headline: Love VUHL!
pros:
Awesome coworkers and management!
Almost a family-like atmosphere!
Everyone is generous with time and talents and willing to help always!
Free snacks whenever you want!
One Bi-weekly 15 minute massage!
No micro-management!
cons: Pay is not wonderful, but benefits make up for this!

headline: Awesome
pros: Good environment, place to grow a career, tons of employee benefits. A great all around place to work. Casual dress code.
cons: Nothing of note to add as a con

headline: Working at Veterans United is a significant part of my lifestyle. It's not just a job.
pros: The culture, no matter how large we get, remains one of the most incredible aspects of this company.  We are passionate about what we do, but we know how to have fun while serving our clients. We care about our employees and their families.  My family embraces all that is Veterans United, not just me.  The leadership genuinely cares about those we serve, as well as the employees fulfilling our duties. We are given opportunities to spread our wings and share ideas.  We don't just deliver results, we do it with the upmost integrity and enthusiasm.
cons: Though it may sound cliche, there is nothing negative I have to share about Veterans United Home Loans. The company encompasses all that it means to live out values.  The "extras" and dedication to employees never ceases to amaze me.  At the same time, we are always focusing on how to make things better, and WOW our clients. No cons for VU.

headline: A workplace where everyone has a great attitude
pros: The coworkers are great to work with, deadlines are reasonable, and everyone is accepting of feedback. Management usually seems to listen to suggestions.
cons: Not as competitive as other employers in the area when it comes to pay. Also, having sick days as part of your vacation time makes people hesitant to take time off for something relaxing or fun because you might need the time off for something important later.

headline: Great company with lots of perks destined to do great things
pros: Pretty much everything. Great work environment, great coworkers. This is a great place to work if you want to give back to the community as well with the Veterans United Foundation raising over $1 million each year to give back to military causes.
cons: Not many cons at all. I really can't even think of one worth putting on here.

headline: An amazing place to work
pros: VUHL does amazing things for employees to make them both happy and more productive (free lunch, massages, etc) but makes them really stand out is the bottom line is not a dollar sign. The true bottom line is the lives touched.
cons: Getting specific feedback about direction and goals can be a little difficult at times.

headline: A Company Culture Where Employees Matter
pros: The company puts a lot into the quality of the environment in which its employees work. It's a place you don't hate to go to every day.
cons: As a quickly growing company, you can expect to switch desks often. Also, challenges come up everyday, which can be a pro or a con.

headline: A company committed to excellence
pros: I have been blown away with the overall awesomeness of Veterans United.  The people who work here are energetic, motivated, fun, hard-working, and welcoming.  Everyone is happy and excited to be a part of such an amazing and growing company.  They are passionate about their jobs and helping people.  The values of the company are not just writing on the wall, but a company culture that is visible in everything done here.  On top of that, the benefits and perks are something I only imagined was possible in my job: free lunches, free massages, fun outings, free healthy (and unhealthy) food and drinks, Nerf gun wars, contests, prizes, games, family get-togethers, lunch & learns...all of which cause you to be surrounded by happy and productive employees.  I'm excited to see where my career here takes me.
cons: If you cannot have fun at work while being productive this isn't the company for you.  Work hard, play hard.  It's not the normal mortgage company or any company for that matter--it's a fun and dynamic culture. Change is very normal around here with the expansion of the company so if you don't like change you might reconsider working here.

headline: Great company with a great company focus. Yes, they expect you to work hard, but the overall corporate culture is great.
pros: Corporate culture, employee growth potential, and work/life balance are all outstanding.
cons: Non-production salaries are lower than competition, but this IS Columbia, MO.

headline: A Company with an end in sight.
pros: A lot of the workers are friendly people/young and very active in the community. VUHL is very charitable and has a reputation to back it up. The offices are brand new and very nice.
cons:
The problem with this organization is that it has hired an weak base for growth. At least 33% of VUHL employees are not competent enough to do their jobs. The reasons many tech start ups grow and make lots of money--highly educated/highly skilled/highly intelligent base of employees and leaders...something VUHL does not have. There are lots of youngsters and that isn't always a bad thing, but for VUHL it is. They just don't have the intellectual talent to stay in business another 10 years. This is a job I am constantly looking forward to replace. I feel like my hard work in college could be better used elsewhere.

On another note, the business model isn't sustainable. Eventually veterans will realize they would much rather have face to face contact with people they owe hundreds of thousands of dollars to. Bottom line, these jobs are not long lasting, are not filled with intellectual capital, and VUHL will not be around forever. Because at this point, you can apply for 5 jobs at vuhl and get all of them without any skills.

headline: Notice how a lot of these reviews are written in similar manners, very shady and it shows
pros: They give you free lunch on Mondays and have a decent benefit package. Salary is OK, but not great. They give a lot to the community.
cons:
Well, for starters, look at the reviews on here. It looks like to me they sent their marketing interns to spend a couple of hours boasting the company. However, this place is not a 4.6/5.0, it is barely a 3.0/5.0. Half of the employees who work here are great. They are friendly, passionate, go-getters, and love their job. The problem is the other half. The half that couldn't get a job in the real professional world. Rude, excuse-makers, and plain ignorant. There are several managers like someone listed below who are a joke. Outside of VUHL, they couldn't manage a fast food restaurant. They don't have any type of structure, either. Don't expect to know what is going on from one day to the next. VUHL does give a lot to the Columbia community, but it comes at the expense of Veterans of our country.

Stop and think what they sell....they in no way have anything better to offer a veteran than a local bank who you can see EVERY day if you needed to. The set up isn't one that seems like it could last for more than 10 years at most.

Too many uneducated people here. It seems like almost everyone is 22 years old and graduated last month. They party a lot but they will never compare to a respectful fortune 500 company with the talent-less people they hire.

headline: A great place to work, learn, and grow.
pros: If you're looking to work for a company that pushes you to better yourself and your community every day, this is the place for you. VUHL is a fast-paced environment where your job description changes as the company continues to grow. You will never get bored with doing mundane tasks 40 hours/week. You will have ample opportunity to learn something new every day from a company that has proven to be an innovator in the industry. Most of all, VUHL engages in countless activities to serve veterans and the community as a whole. Employees are treated like people, and management genuinely cares about your well-being. The perks are talked about in most of these posts (free massages, free snacks, casual dress, etc.), but the greatest benefit you'll receive is the opportunity to grow as an individual and leave every day with more knowledge than you came in with. Their three values are the cornerstone of everything the company does, and were written by the employees themselves. If you work here, you will live them every day.
cons: If you're looking to get by with the bare minimum and are afraid of change, this is not the place for you. You simply won't be able to keep up and will probably be miserable.

headline: Outstanding
pros: The energy in this place is incredible. The management here is all about going after new ideas and trying new things. There is always something new to try, something new to work on. The "go get em" attitude is infectious and makes you want to do more, learn more, try harder and excel. The management and employees are dedicated to giving back to the community. It's not just lip service here. It's the real deal. The Foundation we started is an example of that. It's not like any other company I have ever worked at. I'd highly recommend this as a place to work for anyone.
cons: The growth has been hard to stay on top of. More management experience for new managers.

headline: One of the best internships available while going to school
pros: Everything, free Monday lunches, everyone is friendly, lots of perks, opportunity of advancement, people are all caring, lots and lots of fun.  Very good environment.
cons: Really the only downside to working at VAMortgageCenter.com is that they are hiring people so fast it is very hard to keep up with every and there new positions.

headline: Good Perks
pros: At VAMC we have some good perks like casual dress, golf outings, bowling outings, christmas parties, massages, free lunch mondays.
cons: You have to work hard every day all day. It's stressful but you get paid better than average, so if you don't mind hard work and a fast paced environment it's a good place to be.

headline: One of a kind employer
pros: The people are this company's greatest asset.  Everyone is so great to work with, not just because they are nice people, but because they are all so smart and passionate about their role in the company.  It's a very cool thing to be a part of, and haven't seen any work environment quite like this.  There are lots of other perks too - casual dress, great events, free food (vending machine and fresh food fridge), faith forums, etc.
cons: The company is growing very quickly, and there are growing pains that go along with it.  Sometimes we are understaffed in certain departments, or there is so much going on that changes aren't always communicated to everyone as timely as they should be.  Changes are constant at VAMC, but I guess that also helps us stay ahead of the competition!

headline: Good job for recent graduates
pros: We have a young atmosphere and a lot of fun. It's nice to work with friends I know from college.
cons: We do work odd shifts and long hours and weekends to make sure phones are covered. Perfect job coming out of college to get business experience. Only downside is it's an entry level job so I'll get my experience but not much chance of promotion in company so ill have to look for another job in a year or two.

headline: Party for a few months then a bad hangover
pros: Pay was great, casual dress code, lunch on mondays, massages once a month, easy job, fun parties, lots of parties, basically one big party!
cons: Party with a hangover, get hired get paid and party, then go find a new job. No job security, me and a couple friends all worked there and none of us are left. They just replaced us with new Mizzou graduates. We only know a few people who worked there more than a couple years. It's fun so enjoy it, but know it's a revolving door and you'll get replaced with some interns. Benefits were better at my other job. Commission wasn't as good as my friends had told me, basically just work for your hourly pay.

headline: A company that really cares about their workers
pros: Benefits - Catered lunch on Mondays, Casual Dress, Strong emphasis on work/life balance
cons: Most jobs are in sales. If you like sales, then it's great

headline: Awesome Place to Work!
pros: The company values are amazing.  Be passionate and have fun.  Deliver results with integrity.  Enhance Lives every day.  We come to work every day excited to work hard and serve our clients.  It is remarkable to work for a company that is so well-rounded.  This company is full of high performers.  The people that make up the VAMC team are energetic, fun, smart and caring.  The company values are truly lived out on a daily basis.  One of the most exciting things about working for VAMC is the community involvement.  VAMC gives back in so many ways and makes it easy and exciting for employees to get involved whether it is volunteering at the Food Bank, running in a 5K fundraiser or getting involved with United Way.  I am so proud of this company and of my co-workers.  We strive for excellence in the work we do for our clients by providing amazing customer service, but we also make each other better people every day.
cons: There is a lot of change and growth with this company so it’s really important to be adaptable.  It’s really exciting to be a part of company history as we continue to reach new milestones.
